title: 110_hr3621
content:
The Act titled "Safety, Accountability, and Funding Efficiency for Transportation Act of 2007" emphasizes the importance of conducting cost-benefit analysis before procuring transportation services from private contractors to ensure quality and cost-effectiveness. The Act defines "architectural, engineering, and related services" as various services related to construction projects. It also defines "private contract" as an agreement between a government agency and a private contractor, and "government agency" as a entity receiving Federal funds for transportation projects. The term "private contract" refers to an agreement between a government agency and a private contractor. A "government agency" is defined as an entity receiving Federal funds for surface transportation projects. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Transportation. A "surface transportation project" includes projects eligible for assistance under title 23, United States Code, capital projects, and other transportation-related projects deemed appropriate by the Secretary. SEC. 4. COST-BENEFIT ANALYSIS. For fiscal year 2009 and onwards, Federal funds for surface transportation projects can be used by government agencies for private contracts over $100,000 for architectural, engineering, and related services, but only after conducting a cost-benefit analysis as required by this section. The analysis must include a description of services, cost estimates, and negotiation expenses. The private contract must include a description of services, cost estimates, negotiation expenses, and a comparison of costs between private and government agency performance. The private contract must include a description of services, cost estimates, negotiation expenses, and a comparison of costs between private and government agency performance. Additionally, it should detail staff salaries, office facilities, equipment, and materials costs attributed to the services. Determinations on procurement speed, equipment provision, and estimated unemployment compensation should also be included. The private contract should include estimates for equipment and materials provided by the government agency, costs of unemployment compensation for displaced employees, and the cost of resuming service by the government agency. SEC. 5. DISCLOSURE OF RESULTS OF COST-BENEFIT ANALYSIS.

Government agencies must disclose cost-benefit analysis results for private contracts before entering into them. Results must be submitted to the Secretary for review, provided to registered individuals or entities, and made available for public inspection, including online publication.

SEC. 6. COMMENTS. SEC. 6. COMMENTS.

Within 15 days of a government agency publishing the results of a cost-benefit analysis for a private contract, employees and interested parties can submit written comments challenging the accuracy of the results. Additionally, agency employees can submit competitive bids to provide the services outlined in the contract. The Secretary may waive the application of this Act for private contracts at the request of a government agency if the work is of an emergency, specialty, or intermittent nature and cannot be performed by government employees to avoid underutilization.
